The JPY was the best performing major currency, after a tweak to the BoJ’s bond-buying program pushed the yen higher, although the greenback benefitted elsewhere after reports suggested that the PBoC will remove the counter-cyclical buffer from its yuan fixing mechanism (indicating a move towards a more market-based valuation for the currency). subject: PREVIEW: US to sell USD 24bln 3-year notes at 1300 ET (1800 GMT) on 9 Jan 2018
content:
THIS WEEK’S TREASURY SUPPLY: Excluding bills, the US will this week sell a total of USD 56bln in 3s, 10s and 30s this week (USD 24bln of 3s on Tuesday, USD 20bln in a 10s reopening on Wednesday, USD 12bln in a 30s reopening on Thursday). The sales will raise a net USD 15.5bln in new cash, given the USD 40.5bln maturing at the mid-month settlement, according to TD Securities.

SHORT-END: Yields along the front have risen to nine-year highs at the beginning of 2018 on expectations that the Federal Reserve will continue to raise rates; money markets are pricing in around 62% probability of a hike in March, according to the CME Fedwatch tool, with Fed Funds futures pricing in just over two hikes in 2018 (versus the three hikes pencilled in by the Fed’s latest ‘dots’).

However, despite front-end yields rising, major curves – the 2s10s spread, for instance – have flattened, with 10-year yields continuing to trade between 2.40% and 2.50% this year.

3-YEAR AUCTION: Yields on 3s have cheapened by around 10bps since the last auction cycle, which may provide some support for the auction. Recent auctions have been mixed, clearing very close to the 1pm WI, analysts at Barclays write.

“Final demand has remained stable because while foreign demand has declined, domestic demand has increased,” Barclays writes, “on a three-month moving average, foreign demand has declined 6pp, to 16%, while domestic demand has increased about 5ppts, to 46%.” And Barclays argues that while on-the-run 3s appear rich on a spot basis, that is due to its specialness in repo markets.

PREVIOUS 3-YEAR AUCTION HSTORY (via TD Securities):
- Size: USD 24bln (vs six-month average of USD 24bln)
- High-yield: 1.932% (vs six-auction average of 1.644%)
- Tail: 0.3bps (vs six auction average of 0.0bps)
- Dealers: 33.6% (vs six auction average of 36.1%)
- Directs: 7.4% (vs six auction average of 9.0%)
- Indirects: 59.0% (vs six auction average of 54.9%)

Daily FX Wrap: very volatile trade, but main themes intact
content: Only the JPY has managed to retain a bid tone in outright terms, following reduced Rinban buying of long end JGBs by the BoJ overnight. Usd/Jpy traded mostly under 113.00, albeit with 112.50 proving to be a solid base and bid level. Eur/Jpy tripped stops below 134.40 having fallen through 135.00 during Asian trade and looks set for more downside as the EUR continued to pull-back from recent peaks. Eur/Usd filled at least some stops below 1.1925, and the headline pair could test support and demand around 1.1900, before key technical support at 1.1885, while 1.1947 may stall any rebounds towards 1.1950. CHF, CAD, GBP, AUD, and even the NZD all lost out to the latest broader USD recovery (aided by the PBoC relaxing its CCF on Yuan fixing), as the DXY climbed above 92.600 and close to resistance at 92.663, before 92.956 and then 93.000 for obvious reasons. Usd/Chf is approaching 0.9850, Usd/Cad is up through offers around 1.2450, with Cable only just holding above 1.3500 and stops seen just below the figure. Aud/Usd is testing bids ahead of 0.7800, with chart support at 0.7795 and large option expiries between 0.7810-15 rolling off at the end of the week (2 bn) and Nzd/Usd remains off its near 0.7200 overnight peak, but underpinned by Aud/Nzd cross flows (below 1.0900, with chart support around 1.0861).

content: Heavy selling in USTs, and especially the 10 year future (some 16k lots sold in 2 clips of late) has spilled over to EU debt markets, naturally. The US 10 year yield looks to be forming a base over 2.5% amidst curve bear-steepening despite impending supply on Wednesday and 3s today. Interestingly, this may be building a decent concession, but if Mar10 year notes lose 123-00 support (from a 123-06 low so far) this could yield more downside towards the next tech support area (122-22). Moreover, 122-50 puts have been bought in around 5k lots, possibly vs a sale of 126-00 calls in the same size.

(Newswires / DigiTime)

 

S&P 500

Air Products (APD) – The co. is to acquire Royal Dutch Shell’s (RDS.A) Coal Gasification Technology unit. (Newswires)

Allergan (AGN) – The pharmaceutical co. forecasts FY18 Adj. performance EPS at least (USD) 15.25 vs Exp. 15.80, Forecasts revenue at 15bln-15.3bln vs Exp. 15.61bln. Further, it sees the US Tax Reform ‘broadly neutral’ to its effective tax rate over time. (Newswires)

Apache (APA) – The co. forecasts Q3 adjusted international production between 138k and 140k BOE/d. (Newswires)

AT&T (T) – Huawei Technologies are no longer entering a deal with the co, which would allow Huawei to sell smartphones in the US. (Newswires)

Boston Scientific (BSX) – The co. reports a preliminary Revenue (USD) of 2.41bln vs Exp. 2.35bln, further it forecasts FY17 revenue at about 9.05bln vs Exp. 8.99bln and it expects higher Q4 sales. (Newswires)

Broadcom (AVGO) / Qualcomm (QCOM) – Chinese smartphone makers are concerned over the merger between the two companies. (WSJ)

Ford (F) – The automaker declares a fall in 2017 vehicles sales of 6% Y/Y. Further, it says December China vehicles sales fell 9% Y/Y to over 140,000 units. (Newswires)

Nordstrom (JWN) – The co.’s Rack president, Karen McKibbin is to retire in March, with Geevy Thomas, Chief Innovation Officer, to succeed her. (Newswires)

Raytheon (RTN) – The defence name has been awarded a contract worth more than USD 1.5bln for additional Patriot integrated air and missile defence capability. (Newswires)

Southwest Airlines (LUV) – The airline reports December traffic is up 4.9%. (Newswires)

Target (TGT) – The retailer’s November/December sales up 3.4% and raises Q4 guidance on stronger than expected holiday sales. (Newswires)

Urban Outfitters (URBN) – The co. announces its 2-month net sales for the end of December 21st is up 3.6%. (Newswires)

 

NASDAQ 100

Alphabet (GOOG) – The internet association said on Monday the co. is to introduce voice-controlled virtual assistant in new LG Electronics Inc and Sony Corp tablets. (Newswires)

Amazon (AMZN) – Piper Jaffray increase the retailers price target to (USD) 1400 from 1200. (CNBC)

Facebook (FB) – The social media giant is putting an end to ‘M’, a digital assistant product unveiled two years ago. Further, its Oculus is launching a new wireless VR headset in China (focused on gaming, social networking, and watching video) thanks to a partnership with Xiaomi. (Newswires)

Qualcomm (QCOM) – The chipmaker is to be used by Visteon Corporation’s (VC) next generation cockpit controllers, it also expects to receive EU approval regarding the purchase of NXP Semiconductors (NXPI). Further, the co.’s Smart Audio Platform is now supporting Microsoft’s (MSFT) Cortana, and is to provide support for Android Things, Google’s (GOOG) assistant as well as being qualified by Amazon’s (AMZN) Alexa. Also, it announces Radio Frequency Front end design wins with Google, HTC, LG, Samsung (SSNLF) and Sony Mobile (SNE) and the co.’s Snapdragon has been selected Tata Motors’ (TTM) Jaguar Land Rover for advanced connectivity. OTHER NEWS

DAILY US OPENING NEWS: USD is extending recent recovery gains to just over 92.500 amid reports that the PBoC is planning to suspend the counter-cyclical factor in CNY fixes
content:
• USD is extending recent recovery gains to just over 92.500 amid reports that the PBoC is planning to suspend the counter-cyclical factor in CNY fixes
  • Global European equities are trading higher across the board (Eurostoxx 50 +0.2%) with all sectors (ex-energy) in the green
  • Highlights include APIs, Fed’s Kashkari and supply from the Netherlands, Austria, Germany, UK and the US

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mostly higher as the region mirrored the tone seen in US, where all majors posted fresh record highs but the DJIA still snapped its New Year streak. ASX 200 (+0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) were positive in which commodity names led in Australia and the Japanese benchmark outperformed as it played catch up on return from the extended weekend. However, some of the gains in Japan were later pared on tapering concerns after the BoJ reduced its Rinban announcement for longer dated bonds. Elsewhere, KOSPI (-0.1%) was dampened after index-heavyweight Samsung Electronics missed on Q4 preliminary results, while both Hang Seng (+0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) also gained despite initial cautiousness on further inaction by the PBoC which resulted to a net daily drain of CNY 130bln. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower by about 15 ticks on concern of BoJ tapering after the Rinban announcement saw a reduction of buying in 10yr-25yr maturities to JPY 190bln from JPY 200bln, as well as the amount in 25yr+ maturities which was cut to JPY 80bln from JPY 90bln.

China are to suspend the counter-cyclical factor in the CNY fix, according to sources. (Newswires)

PBoC skipped open market operations again today. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.4968 (Prev. 6.4832)   

US

US Special Counsel Mueller told President Trump's lawyers that he may want a one-on-one interview with President Trump soon. (Newswires)

EU/UK

UK Brexit Secretary David Davis has consulted lawyers over the EU’s preparations for a no-deal Brexit, which is said to harm British business and breach the UK’s rights as a member state, according to reports in FT. (FT)


GEOPOLITICS

North Korea delegation head said that inter-Korean talks were expected to go well and that he hoped to achieve precious results. Furthermore, it was later reported after discussions finished, that North Korea is to send a delegation of high-ranking officials, athletes and cheering squad to the Olympics. (Newswires)

US Secretary of State Tillerson and Secretary of Defense Mattis are reportedly trying to hold President Trump back from striking North Korea, while National Security Adviser McMaster is in favour of a bloody nose attack. (Business Insider)


EQUITIES

Global European equities are trading higher across the board (Eurostoxx 50 +0.2%) with all sectors (ex-energy) in the green. Performance is relatively broad-based with some slight outperformance in material names. Focus has also been on the UK supermarket sector after the latest trading update from Morrisons (+2.6%) sent their shares to the top of the FTSE alongside the latest Kantar and Nielsen reports. Elsewhere, focus has also fallen on UK homebuilders with Persimmon shares initially  supported by upbeat guidance before upside momentum then dissipated. British American Tobacco shares have been supported after stating that the impact of new US tax legislation would result in a benefit of 6% to FY 2018 EPS.

FX

In FX, USD is extending recent recovery gains to just over 92.500, with the Greenback getting a boost from reports that the PBoC is planning to suspend the counter-cyclical factor in CNY fixes, which saw USD/CNH spike to 6.51520 from 6.50340 following the earlier 6.4968 USD/CNY mid-point setting. JPY firmer and the G10 outperformer on reduced Rinban activity overnight which alongside monthly BoJ data suggests a concerted slowdown in JGB buying. USD/JPY down to 112.50 from 113.00+ at one stage, but bids around the low held and broader US Dollar gains now nudging the pair back up towards 113.00 again.  EUR is still on the back foot across the board as more long positions are trimmed, with EUR/USD now under 1.1950 and eyeing stops said to be in place at 1.1925. AUD/CAD/NZD all off best levels vs their US counterpart, with AUD/USD above 0.7850 on much better than expected Aussie building approvals data overnight, but now back down under 0.7825, USD/CAD looking firmer over 1.2400 after another dip below the figure (another uptick in oil prices and solid BoC business outlook survey supporting the Loonie) and NZD/USD down around 0.7170 having almost touched 0.7200.

 


FIXED INCOME

A somewhat belated and limp uptick in Bunds and Gilts given the well-received German and UK supply offerings with the only slight fly in the ointment perhaps coming via the 2027 DMO average yield. However, the 10 year Eurex benchmark is now just above parity at 161.83 (+3 ticks vs -24 ticks at worst) and its Liffe peer is nudging back up toward the upper end of a 124.63-43 range vs yesterday’s 124.80 close. The rather muted price moves suggest more supply related topside pressure looming ahead of the start of US refunding and with plenty of EU issuance still to come this week, not to mention corporate deals. US Treasuries also seem to have supply in mind with a steeper bias across the maturity curve, and the 10 year yield just crossing 2.5% again.

COMMODITIES

In the commodities complex, WTI and Brent crude prices were initially trading in close proximity to recent highs in a continuation of sentiment yesterday after expectations of a draw of 4.1mln bbls for this week’s inventory data. Furthermore, OPEC officials suggested that the Iran situation was being monitored, and output will only be raised in the event that there is a significant and sustained disruption to output. However, prices then began to be dragged lower after comments from the Iranian energy minister who claimed that OPEC does not want oil prices above USD 60/bbl. In metals markets, the recovery in the USD placed some weight on precious metals (Silver tested USD 17.00/oz to the downside) after a relatively uneventful Asia-Pac session. Elsewhere,  Chinese iron ore futures were seen higher overnight as production cutbacks in China continues to sway sentiment. 

Iran oil minister Zanganeh says OPEC does not want oil prices above USD 60/bbl. (Newswires)

Indian Trade Ministry official says comprehensive gold policy will likely be prepared by March and that there is also a likelihood for the recommendation of lower import tax on gold. (Newswires)

subject: EU MID-SESSION UPDATE: European equities higher with all sectors (ex-energy) in the green. USD rebounding against its peers, boosted by PBoC CNY action
content:
European equities are trading higher across the board (Eurostoxx 50 +0.2%) with all ten sectors in the green. Performance is relatively broad-based with some slight outperformance in material names. Focus has also been on the UK supermarket sector after the latest trading update from Morrisons (+2.6%) sent their shares to the top of the FTSE alongside the latest Kantar and Nielsen reports. UK debt appears to be making a concession for upcoming supply from the DMO in a classic pre-auction set up fashion, with the secondary 10 year yield back up around 1.25% and bang on the coupon price of today’s issue. On that note, the Buba has set a 0.5% coupon on its new 10 year Bund ahead of Wednesday’s launch, which could draw cash rates from the current circa 0.44% level. FX Morning Colour: BoJ bolsters Jpy, Eur buffeted again
content:
FX Morning Colour: BoJ bolsters Jpy, Eur buffeted again

JPY

Firmer and the G10 outperformer on reduced Rinban activity overnight which alongside monthly BoJ data suggests a concerted slowdown in JGB buying. Usd/Jpy down to 112.50 from 113.00+ at one stage, but bids around the low held and broader US Dollar gains now nudging the pair back up towards 113.00 again. Offers at 112.80 have been absorbed, with more touted at 113.00 where a near 1 bn option expiry resides. Eur/Jpy still looking bearish below 135.00 in contrast.

EUR

Still on the back foot across the board as more long positions are trimmed, with Eur/Usd now under 1.1950 and eyeing stops said to be in place at 1.1925. A hefty expiry at the 1.1950 strike (1 bn) may stem further losses, but much bigger interests via a combination of vanilla and digital expiries at 1.1985 could be too far from the action to exert meaningful influence.

DXY

Extending recent recovery gains to just over 92.500, with the Greenback getting a boost from reports that the PBoC is planning to suspend the counter-cyclical factor in CNY fixes, which saw Usd/Cnh spike to 6.51520 from 6.50340 following the earlier 6.4968 Usd/Cny mid-point setting.

The Usd index remains on target to challenge resistance at 92.663, 92.956 and then a stronger level around 93.163.

AUD/CAD/NZD

All off best levels vs their US counterpart, with Aud/Usd above 0.7850 on much better than expected Aussie building approvals data overnight, but now back down under 0.7825, Usd/Cad looking firmer over 1.2400 after another dip below the figure (another uptick in oil prices and solid BoC business outlook survey supporting the Loonie) and Nzd/Usd down around 0.7170 having almost touched 0.7200.

GBP/CHF

Cable testing support at the lower end of recent ranges (1.3500-1.3600) and Usd/Chf above 0.9800 despite a significant, albeit still soft, Swiss retail sales beat, as the Dollar revival gathers momentum.

analysis_details: Policy makers had previously added a “counter-cyclical factor”, which analysts noted would give authorities more control over the fixing and restrain the influence of market pricing.

subject: Bunds: bearish Eurex open on multiple factors
content: In addition to decent German data beats bang on the Eurex open, Bunds have been marked down and are extending losses on supply considerations ahead of EU and US auctions today, while the BoJ’s reduced Rinban JGB purchases overnight are also weighing on sentiment. Looking at price action in more detail, the 10 year debt future kicked off at 161.67 vs yesterday’s 161.80 close and after a fleeting uptick to 161.68 the benchmark recoiled to a 161.56 low (-24 ticks), with the corresponding yield bouncing firmly towards 0.45% having tested support just ahead of 0.4% on Tuesday. To recap, with the BoJ apparently unwinding some QE and the ECB tapering its bond buying as of this month the bias for fixed remains towards weaker futures/higher cash rates, and below 161.50 for the front month contract exposes minor tech and short term chart supports before the key downside target at 161.18.

subject: Daily Bond Auction Preview: Supply from UK, Germany, Austria, Netherlands
content:
AUCTION PREVIEW: Dutch EUR 1.5-2.5bln 2024 DSL Auction

Rabobank: The DSL Jan 2024 is the shortest maturity Dutch govvie with a positive yield and this could be supportive at the auction. The bond also appears to offer value versus swap compared to its peers on the Dutch curve.

On the issue date at 0900GMT, the DSTA will announce the price at which Primary Dealers may buy the issue. As usual, the issuance will take the form of a tap auction, during which the DSTA may revise the price at any time.

 

AUCTION PREVIEW: Austrian EUR 1.38bln 0.5% 2027 and 2047 Bond Auction

SocGen: EGB spreads look resilient for now, with supply weighing only at the margin. This week sees sizeable issuance, with the reopening of the 2024 DSL, and 2027 and 2047 RAGBs on Tuesday. Amongst these three bonds, only the RAGB April 2027 has seen interesting concession.

There is some competing supply this week which may deter investors, but analysts at IFR suspect that the auctions will go week as Austria is a high-quality name and an infrequent borrower and therefore there is likely to be demand.

In terms of historical data

0.5% 2027 prev. b/c 4.249, average yield 0.476%

1.5% 2047 prev. 2.84, average yield 1.495%

Bids are submitted by 1000GMT and results are published shortly after.

 

AUCTION PREVIEW: ECB 7-Day MRO

On December 19th the ECB announced that EUR 3.372bln was allotted in its 14-day MRO operation. Results are usually published around 1030GMT.

 

AUCTION PREVIEW: German EUR 0.5bln I/L 0.1% 2046 Auction

In terms of historical data:

Prev. b/c 1.4, real yield -0.36%

Bids are submitted by 1030GMT and results are published shortly after.

 

AUCTION PREVIEW: UK GBP 2.25bln 1.25% 2027 Gilt Auction

SocGen: From a relative value perspective, the signs are mixed, with the auction bond looking fair if z-spreads are plotted against duration, but cheap (close to 4bp) if maturity is used. Aside from relative value arguments, there should be decent pent-up demand for gilts. There has been a lack of recent issuance and it is close to two months since the 10y was last auctioned. Auctions of the 10y seldom go badly, with the average bid/cover over all auctions at 2.24x and average tail at just over 0.2bp. With asset managers tending to have cash to allocate at the start of the year, and with the gilts that pay coupon on 22 January scheduled to go ex-dividend on Thursday, we think the auction should go well.

In terms of historical data:

Prev. b/c 2.15, average yield 1.317%

Bids are submitted by 1030GMT and results are published shortly after.

US to sell USD 24bln 3-year notes at 1300 ET (1800 GMT) on 9 Jan 2018

THIS WEEK’S TREASURY SUPPLY: Excluding bills, the US will this week sell a total of USD 56bln in 3s, 10s and 30s this week (USD 24bln of 3s on Tuesday, USD 20bln in a 10s reopening on Wednesday, USD 12bln in a 30s reopening on Thursday). The sales will raise a net USD 15.5bln in new cash, given the USD 40.5bln maturing at the mid-month settlement, according to TD Securities.

SHORT-END: Yields along the front have risen to nine-year highs at the beginning of 2018 on expectations that the Federal Reserve will continue to raise rates; money markets are pricing in around 62% probability of a hike in March, according to the CME Fedwatch tool, with Fed Funds futures pricing in just over two hikes in 2018 (versus the three hikes pencilled in by the Fed’s latest ‘dots’).

However, despite front-end yields rising, major curves – the 2s10s spread, for instance – have flattened, with 10-year yields continuing to trade between 2.40% and 2.50% this year.

3-YEAR AUCTION: Yields on 3s have cheapened by around 10bps since the last auction cycle, which may provide some support for the auction. Recent auctions have been mixed, clearing very close to the 1pm WI, analysts at Barclays write.

“Final demand has remained stable because while foreign demand has declined, domestic demand has increased,” Barclays writes, “on a three-month moving average, foreign demand has declined 6pp, to 16%, while domestic demand has increased about 5ppts, to 46%.” And Barclays argues that while on-the-run 3s appear rich on a spot basis, that is due to its specialness in repo markets.

PREVIOUS 3-YEAR AUCTION HSTORY (via TD Securities):

- Size: USD 24bln (vs six-month average of USD 24bln)
- High-yield: 1.932% (vs six-auction average of 1.644%)
- Tail: 0.3bps (vs six auction average of 0.0bps)
- Dealers: 33.6% (vs six auction average of 36.1%)
- Directs: 7.4% (vs six auction average of 9.0%)
- Indirects: 59.0% (vs six auction average of 54.9%)

DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian Asia equity markets traded mostly higher as the region mirrored the tone seen in US, where all majors posted fresh record highs
content:
• Asian Asia equity markets traded mostly higher as the region mirrored the tone seen in US, where all majors posted fresh record highs
  • JPY strengthened on a reduced Rinban announcement in which USD/JPY slipped below 113.00
  • Looking ahead, highlights include APIs, Fed’s Kashkari and supply from the Netherlands, Austria, Germany, UK and the US

ASIA

Asia equity markets traded mostly higher as the region mirrored the tone seen in US, where all majors posted fresh record highs but the DJIA still snapped its New Year streak. ASX 200 (+0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) were positive in which commodity names led in Australia and the Japanese benchmark outperformed as it played catch up on return from the extended weekend. However, some of the gains in Japan were later pared on tapering concerns after the BoJ reduced its Rinban announcement for longer dated bonds. Elsewhere, KOSPI (-0.4%) was dampened after index-heavyweight Samsung Electronics missed on Q4 preliminary results, while both Hang Seng (+0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) also gained despite initial cautiousness on further inaction by the PBoC which resulted to a net daily drain of CNY 130bln. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower by about 15 ticks on concern of BoJ tapering after the Rinban announcement saw a reduction of buying in 10yr-25yr maturities to JPY 190bln from JPY 200bln, as well as the amount in 25yr+ maturities which was cut to JPY 80bln from JPY 90bln.

PBoC skipped open market operations again today. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.4968 (Prev. 6.4832)  


UK/EU

UK BRC Retail Sales YY (Dec) 0.60% vs. Exp. 0.30% (Prev. 0.60%). (Newswires)

UK Brexit Secretary David Davis consulted lawyers over the EU’s preparations for a no-deal Brexit, which is said to harm British business and breach the UK’s rights as a member state. (FT)

During UK PM May’s cabinet reshuffle yesterday, Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt, successfully faced down the Prime Minister when she asked him to become business secretary, forcing Mrs May to tear up her plans to promote or move other ministers who were already pencilled in. Furthermore, Justine Greening, who had been asked to become the new Work and Pensions Secretary, dug in her heels during two and a half hours inside Downing Street, refusing the new role before finally announcing she was quitting the Government altogether. (Telegraph)


FX

JPY strengthened on the reduced Rinban announcement in which USD/JPY slipped below 113.00 and GBP/JPY gave up the 153.00 handle. Antipodeans were also firmer against the greenback with AUD/USD underpinned after stronger than expected Building Approvals, while NZD/USD eyed a test of the 0.7200 level to the upside.

Australian Building Approvals (Nov) M/M 11.7% vs. Exp. -1.3% (Prev. 0.9%). (Newswires)
Australian Building Approvals (Nov) Y/Y 17.1% vs. Exp. 4.6% (Prev. 18.4%)


COMMODITIES

WTI crude futures extended on gains overnight with prices back above USD 62/bbl. The unrest in Iran continues to be in focus, with OPEC officials suggesting that the situation was being monitored, and output will only be raised in the event that there is a significant and sustained disruption to output. Elsewhere, a poll suggested expectations for a draw of 4.1mln barrels in headline crude inventories. The metals complex was less eventful with both gold and copper relatively flat on the day despite the positive risk tone and early strength in Dalian iron ore prices.

India Trade Ministry official said comprehensive gold policy will likely be prepared by March and that there is also a likelihood for the recommendation of lower import tax on gold. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

North Korea delegation head said that inter-Korean talks were expected to go well and that he hoped to achieve precious results. Furthermore, it was later reported after discussions finished, that North Korea is to send a delegation of high-ranking officials, athletes and cheering squad to the Olympics. (Newswires)

US Secretary of State Tillerson and Secretary of Defense Mattis are reportedly trying to hold President Trump back from striking North Korea, while National Security Adviser McMaster is in favour of a bloody nose attack. (Business Insider)

US officials were said to consider North Korea strike feasibility, according to press reports. (WSJ)
 

US

US yields were little change on the day, with a small bias towards a steeper curve. Attention now moves towards this week’s supply out of the US Treasury. Excluding bills, the US will this week sell a total of USD 56bln in 3s, 10s and 30s this week ($24bln of 3s on Tuesday, $20bln in a 10s reopening on Wednesday, $12bln in a 30s reopening on Thursday). The sales will raise a net $15.5bln in new cash, given the $40.5bln maturing at the mid-month settlement.

Fed’s Bostic (voter) struck a dovish tone, arguing that a lack of wages and prices pressures should keep the Fed cautious in raising rates. Bostic suggested that there was no need to hike rates three times in 2018 (the Fed’s ‘dots’ have pencilled in three hikes in 2018). The Atlanta Fed president also warned on yield curve inversion, saying he did not want Fed policy to drive a yield curve inversion, and will be closely watching long-term yields when voting on rates.

US Special Counsel Mueller told President Trump's lawyers that he may want a one-on-one interview with President Trump soon. (Newswires)
